name: Mapo Tofu
description: For the classic version, use beef. It pairs beautifully with the other robust ingredients.
recipeIngredient: 14 to 16 ounces medium or medium-firm tofu
6 ounces ground beef or pork, fattier kind preferred, roughly chopped to loosen
2 1/2 to 3 tablespoons chile bean sauce, (Pixian kind preferred)
2  large green onions, (white and green parts, cut on the diagonal into pieces about 1 1/2 inches long)
1 1/2 tablespoons cornstarch dissolved in 3 tablespoons water

recipeInstructions.text: Cut the tofu into 1/2-inch cubes and put into a bowl. Bring a kettle of water to a rolling boil. Turn off the heat and when the boiling subsides, pour water over the tofu to cover. Set aside for 15 minutes.
recipeInstructions.name: Cut the tofu into 1/2-inch cubes and put into a bowl. Bring a kettle of water to a rolling boil. Turn off the heat and when the boiling subsides, pour water over the tofu to cover. Set aside for 15 minutes.

recipeInstructions.text: Meanwhile, measure out 1 1/3 cups of water (the stuff you just boiled is fine) and set aside near the stove. You’ll be using it later for the sauce.
recipeInstructions.name: Meanwhile, measure out 1 1/3 cups of water (the stuff you just boiled is fine) and set aside near the stove. You’ll be using it later for the sauce.

recipeInstructions.text: In a large wok or skillet, toast the peppercorn over medium heat for 2 to 3 minutes, until richly fragrant and slightly darkened; you may see a wisp of smoke. Let it cool briefly, then pound with a mortar and pestle or grind in a spice grinder. Set aside.
recipeInstructions.name: In a large wok or skillet, toast the peppercorn over medium heat for 2 to 3 minutes, until richly fragrant and slightly darkened; you may see a wisp of smoke. Let it cool briefly, then pound with a mortar and pestle or grind in a spice grinder. Set aside.

recipeInstructions.text: Drain the tofu in a strainer or colander and put it near the stove. As with all stir-fries, assemble your ingredients next to the stove.
recipeInstructions.name: Drain the tofu in a strainer or colander and put it near the stove. As with all stir-fries, assemble your ingredients next to the stove.

recipeInstructions.text: Heat the oil in the wok or skillet over high heat. Add the beef, stirring and mashing into small pieces until crumbly and cooked through, about 2 minutes. Add the ginger, chile flakes, fermented black beans, and chile sauce. Cook for about 2 minutes, stirring constantly, until the beef is a rich reddish-brown color and the chile sauce has turned the oil slightly red. Add the sugar and soy sauce, stir to combine, then add the tofu. Gently stir or give the wok a shake to combine without breaking up the tofu much.

recipeInstructions.text: Pour in the 1 1/3 cups water you set aside earlier. Bring to a vigorous simmer, and cook for about 3 minutes to allow the tofu to absorb the flavors of the sauce.
recipeInstructions.name: Pour in the 1 1/3 cups water you set aside earlier. Bring to a vigorous simmer, and cook for about 3 minutes to allow the tofu to absorb the flavors of the sauce.

recipeInstructions.text: Taste the sauce and add a pinch of salt or sugar, if needed. Add the green onion and stir to combine. Give the cornstarch one last stir, then pour enough into the wok to thicken the sauce. You may not need to use it all. In Sichuan, the sauce is more soupy than gravylike. Sprinkle in the ground peppercorn, give the mixture one last stir to incorporate, then transfer to a shallow bowl. Serve immediately with lots of hot rice.

review.reviewBody: Working from home and sheltering in place.  I had all the ingredients on hand for a change.  So quick and easy.  And of course delicious.  Didn't add the Sichuan peppercorns since I didn't have it and it was still fabulous.
Your recipYour recipe is similar to the one I have used for years ... but I a 1-2 cubes of dofo ru for extra umami ... does not affect taste.
